title: By “law of desire,” I do not mean to invoke the psychoanalytical sense of the phrase, as that includes conceptual distinctions and elaboration that are beyond the scope of this book. Instead, by “desire” I mean, following Georg Simmel in The Philosophy of Money, simply the subjective complement of value. By “law of desire” I mean the supposition that the acquisition of desired objects underlies 248 Notes to pages 99–107 all human motivation, which in a fabliau context entails that desires for objects pertaining to the individual body, whether for “survival” or “the satisfaction of appetite
